# Embedding Graphs in `uncompiled`

## What's this about?

As a Data scientist, I spend a lot of time and effort relaying information derived from data. Visualization is an incredible tool to do this, so a sane workflow for integrating visualization into a platform like this is kindof high priority. There are literally thousands of ways we might accomplish this, so we'll just do a sampling that exhibit the most common and useful tools and approaches, high-level commercial solutions (Google Sheets, Plotly Chart Studio) down to the infinitely-granular DIY approach. For the purposes of demonstration, we'll set a simple goal; Let's make a column chart using the following values I literally just made up:

```js
const data = [1, 2, 5, 7, 10, 20, 33, 40, 70, 100];
```

## General Advice

For any of these approaches, you'll need to make some typesetting choices. Do you want the graph to occupy the same space as the main column of text, or the full page? You will (likely) need to edit the styling on the embeds accordingly. Pay attention wherever you see a `width` or a `height`.

## External Images

If you perform your analysis in a local tool (e.g. Excel, SPSS, Stata, etc.), you probably export images. To show such graphs in `uncompiled`, you can simply post the image somewhere online (e.g. your `uncompiled` repository) and create a markdown image linking to it, like so:

![Excel Version](images/excelChart.png)

When you create images for [R Markdown](https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/), it does a fancy trick: it generates the image as a binary string, and then embeds the string directly in the text of the document. That way there's no external dependency (i.e. you don't need to do the post-image-on-internet step independently). To see this in action, inspect the following [`ggplot2`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/) version of our graph[For posterity, the R script to generate it is:<br>`library(ggplot2)`<br>`data <- data.frame(data = c(1, 2, 5, 7, 10, 20, 33, 40, 70, 100))`<br>`ggplot(data, aes(x = seq(1, 10), y = data)) + geom_col()`](sidenote):

![ggplot](data:image/png;base64,)

If you check it out in your browser's developer tools, you'll see that the `src` attribute isn't a regular URL, but a data url. The entire image is encoded in that string, saved in this markdown document. This is a good option if you don't want the hassle of managing your document and images separately.

## Google Sheets

Perhaps the simplest approach to getting dataviz onto `uncompiled` sites is to generate the graphs in a simple online analytics tool like [Google Sheets](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/). Here's a boring example:

<iframe src="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vQu3dr5jVGm5pHP_RGp0EHj16dHI7-TY6_YT8hgi21jUXlzwroo5bsf7X1K6zX35D0n3K8En0SSQSyL/pubchart?oid=669224768&amp;format=interactive"></iframe>

To do this, we merely create a spreadsheet with our values, generate the chart, and then publish it. Sheets give you the `iframe` string, and you copy and paste it into your `uncompiled` markdown page.

## Plotly Chart Studio

If you require a more advanced visualization option, you can do a lot worse than [Plotly Chart Studio](https://chart-studio.plotly.com/create/#/). Here's [what our bar graph looks like there](https://plotly.com/~AABoyles/39/):

<iframe width="900" height="400" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" src="//plotly.com/~AABoyles/39.embed"></iframe>

The embedding workflow is effectively identical to Google Sheets, though the flexibility of [Plotly](https://plotly.com/javascript/) is manifest in a somewhat more complex interface.

## Observable

We can create truly bespoke visualizations with more flexible solutions like Observable Notebooks. Observable works by exposing a [weird sort-of Javascript](https://observablehq.com/@observablehq/observables-not-javascript) notebook environment. (You get used to it eventually.) From there, you can embed individual cells with specific visualizations:

<iframe width="100%" height="484" frameborder="0"
  src="https://observablehq.com/embed/@aaboyles/simple-bar-chart-demo?cell=chart"></iframe>

If the iframe gives you any grief, Observable has published [this handy guide to troubleshooting embeddings](https://observablehq.com/@observablehq/troubleshooting-embedding).

## CodePen

Does the idosyncratic approach of Observable get in your way too much? Want to just write Javascript? You can always use a Javascript sandbox service like [CodePen](https://codepen.io/). Here's what it looks like there:

<iframe height="204" scrolling="no" title="WNGgPyz" src="https://codepen.io/aaboyles/embed/WNGgPyz?height=204&theme-id=light&default-tab=result" frameborder="no" loading="lazy" allowtransparency="true" allowfullscreen="true">
  See the Pen <a href='https://codepen.io/aaboyles/pen/WNGgPyz'>WNGgPyz</a> by Anthony Boyles
  (<a href='https://codepen.io/aaboyles'>@aaboyles</a>) on <a href='https://codepen.io'>CodePen</a>.
</iframe>[If this is blank, try clicking "Rerun".](sidenote)

## Roll Your Own

If you absolutely must do it yourself, as it were, there is one final option. You can write your own Javascript and drop it into your markdown. For example, here's our meaningless bar chart made with [D3](https://d3js.org/):

<div id="d3graph"></div>
<script src="https://d3js.org/d3.v6.min.js"></script>
<script>
  let width = window.innerWidth * 0.55;
  let height = 100;
  let data = [1,2,5,7,10,20,33,40,70,100];
  let svg = d3.select('#d3graph').append("svg")
    .attr("width", "55%")
    .attr("height", "100px");
  svg.selectAll(".bar")
    .data(data)
  .enter().append("rect")
    .attr("class", "bar")
    .attr("x", (d, i) => i*width/data.length)
    .attr("width", width/(1+data.length))
    .attr("y", d => height - d)
    .attr("height", d => d)
    .attr("fill", "blue");
</script>

The code to accomplish this is reasonably simple[Uh, for a D3 visualization. I won't go into how it works here, but there are many tutorials online to bridge this gap, if you wish to develop D3 competency.](sidenote):

```md
<div id="d3graph"></div>
<script src="https://d3js.org/d3.v6.min.js"></script>
<script>
let width = window.innerWidth * 0.55;
let height = 100;
let data = [1,2,5,7,10,20,33,40,70,100];
let svg = d3.select('#d3graph').append("svg")
  .attr("width", "55%")
  .attr("height", "400px");
svg.selectAll(".bar")
  .data(data)
.enter().append("rect")
  .attr("class", "bar")
  .attr("x", (d, i) => i*width/data.length)
  .attr("width", width/(1+data.length))
  .attr("y", d => height - d)
  .attr("height", d => d)
  .attr("fill", "blue");
</script>
```

There are a few things to note about this. First note that it's HTML, which is [always valid markdown](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#html) ([except when it isn't](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5266134/best-practice-for-allowing-markdown-in-python-while-preventing-xss-attacks/)). See that we create the `div` where we put the visualization as HTML--this allows us to place the visualization in the document flow where we expect it. If we didn't, we'd need to do some fancy counting-based nonsense to get it in the correct place.

Also note that we can load external scripts by simply including a script tag with an `src`. There's a bit of weird hacking in `uncompiled` to get this to work at all. This gives me concerns about the long-term viability of such approaches. For example, one conceivable failure mode is that your imported script kicks off a long-running process, but your Javascript begins executing before it's ready. If you find that you cannot do something and think latency may be the culprit, I can only offer reasonable apologies and encourage you to leverage a solution that balances the flexibility you were looking for with the robustness of embedding (i.e. use an Observable Notebook).

You're ignoring that? OK. One (bad) thing you can try is adding a wait-loop. Don't do this in general, but it will solve this specific problem on this specific platform. It goes a little something like this:

```js
function makeGraph(){ /* The code to do your thing */ }

let waitloop = setInterval(() => {
  if(typeof d3 == "undefined") return;
  makeGraph();
  clearInterval(waitloop);
}, 1000);
```

All we've done set the browser to check every second if it has access to a global resource called `d3`. If it does, then we can go ahead and use it to generate a graph. If it doesn't, it waits 1000ms and tries again. Again, don't do this in general, but I can envision it solving a problem once in a while.

...Which I hope throws into stark relief why I started this guide with embedding external visualizations. Just because we can do something does not mean we should. All the same, I won't hold it against you if you discover that you simply must manipulate something on the page directly yourself in order to accomplish your goals. Just be warned you're going to be fighting an uphill battle.
